sentences.sentence: By Jairo Yunis and Keyli LoeppkyIn a true economic union, you would expect to see seamless movement of goods, services, and labour across internal borders.

In Canada, unfortunately, you don't.The Canadian Federation of Independent Business (CFIB)(https://financialpost.com/tag/canadian-federation-of-independent-business/)'s latest "State of Internal Trade" report(https://www.cfib-fcei.ca/hubfs/advocacy/pdf/2023/2023-07-internal-trade-report-card-2023-en.pdf) shows there are still significant barriers to trade(https://financialpost.com/tag/trade/) between Canada's provinces and territories, and governments are moving at a snail's pace when it comes to removing them.Canada's small businesses want change: 88 per cent call on governments to remove internal trade barriers that drive up costs and hamper productivity.

Frustrations around compliance costs, registering workers in multiple workers' compensation programs or following the patchwork of occupational health and safety rules across the country are some of the unnecessary headaches for small-business owners, who have faced a host of challenges over the past three years.It's not just businesses that stand to gain from removing internal trade barriers, however.
All Canadians would be better off.

It is nothing short of astounding that, six years into the Canadian Free Trade Agreement, Canadians are still unable to order and ship Canadian alcohol products from other provinces, purchase meat inspected in another province or work in more than one province without navigating excessive hurdles.

These are just a few cases of nonsensical barriers whose removal is long overdue.There has been some modest progress recently - the federal government's internal trade action plan, even if it is still more plan than action, or the introduction of a physician registry in the Atlantic provinces - but the overall pace of change has been frustratingly slow.
It is high time for a new approach.CFIB's report offers just that: blanket mutual recognition of provincial and territorial regulatory standards.
Canada is a diverse country, but provinces and territories are hardly complete strangers.
Surely they can recognize each other's regulations.
If a business meets health and safety standards in one province, those standards should be recognized across the nation.
As one Alberta small-business owner asked: "Is a cookie that's made in Ontario not fit for an Albertan to eat?

"A recent Macdonald-Laurier Institute report(https://macdonaldlaurier.ca/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/20220911_Interprovincial_trade_Manuch_Tombe_PAPER_FWeb.pdf) commissioned by the government of Alberta showed that implementing mutual recognition could grow our economy by 4.4 to 7.9 per cent over the long term.

That's an additional $100 to $200 billion in economic benefits per year - nearly two-thirds what the country spends on health care each year.Despite the clearly non-trivial gains available, our governments have for decades favoured a narrow, protectionist approach(https://financialpost.com/opinion/cheer-new-zealand-dairy-trade-battle-canada) that picks away at barriers one by one.
There are small signs that may be changing, however.

Inclusion of mutual recognition in the work plan of the federal-provincial "Regulatory Reconciliation and Cooperation Table," coupled with the federal government's commitment to establish a mutual recognition framework and allocate funds to this goal, are two steps forward.

Let's see if these plans become reality and make a difference on the ground for Canadians.The world doesn't need a China-U.S. economic war(https://financialpost.com/opinion/jack-mintz-world-doesnt-need-china-u-s-economic-war)Statcan focuses on inflation trees and misses the forest(https://financialpost.com/opinion/statcan-inflation-trees-misses-forest)Case for refurbishing Pickering nuclear plant(https://financialpost.com/opinion/case-for-refurbishing-pickering-nuclear-plant)At the Council of Federation meeting in Winnipeg this week, issues such as affordability, health care(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opseu-health-care-commercial-wrong-outsouring-isnt-privatization) and labour shortages(https://financialpost.com/news/economy/labour-shortages-canada-highly-educated-talent) are likely to take centre stage, and understandably so.
But removing internal trade barriers and instituting mutual recognition need to be near the top of the agenda, too.
With Canada's productivity stagnating or even declining, removing internal trade barriers is no longer a matter of convenience: it is vital to achieving economic prosperity.

We owe it to workers and small businesses - to all of us, really - to seize this opportunity to build a stronger, more united and more prosperous Canada.Jairo Yunis is economist for Western Canada at the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, where Keyli Loeppky is director, interprovincial affairs.
@COPYRIGHT=Â© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
